channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: 18 People Abducted in Baghdad Are Found Dead
item.description: The bodies were dumped on a farm near the predominantly Sunni neighborhood where they were rounded up the night before, according to the police.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: In London ‘Slave’ Case, Lost Under a Maoist Guru’s Spell
item.description: After three women said they were held against their will for 30 years in a South London home, a strange tale has emerged.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Takeda Hires Glaxo Executive as Chief Operating Officer
item.description: The drug giant’s hiring of Christophe Weber, a French national, makes it the latest Japanese company to turn to a foreigner for a top post.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: London Mayor Draws Ire Over Comments on Inequality
item.description: No stranger to gaffes, Boris Johnson, who many believe wants to succeed David Cameron as prime minister, suggested that Britain’s poor were victims of low IQ and that greed is good.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Friendship Is Rekindled With Albania
item.description: China’s cultural exchange program, the Confucius Institute, opens its first branch in the Mediterranean country, an old Communist ally from the 1960s and ’70s.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A signpost of earlier days: An Albanian drives a tractor marked "People's Republic of China."

item.title: E.U. Grapples With Disappointment Over Ukraine
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, who last week ditched plans to sign trade agreements with the European Union, found himself confronted by the Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Street protests in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, continued on Friday.

item.title: Out of Syria, Into a European Maze
item.description: As war rages on, more refugees are risking a journey across the Mediterranean in hopes of new lives in Europe. Instead, many find uncertainty and frustration.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Moderate Recovery Is Forecast for India
item.description: A three-month growth spurt at rate of 4.8% was led by banking and insurance.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: China Scrambles Jets for First Time in New Air Zone
item.description: The Chinese said two American surveillance planes and 10 Japanese aircraft had been identified in the zone, established by China last week.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 29
item.description: The Mypadu Beach in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Children playing at Mypadu Beach in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: Protesters Enter Headquarters of Thailand’s Army
item.description: The intrusion of protesters at the Royal Thai Army compound on Friday capped a week of dramatic and provocative gestures against the country’s most influential political family.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A crowd of protesters broke the padlocked gate at the Royal Thai Army compound in Bangkok on Friday.

item.title: China Sends Jets to Identify Flights by U.S. and Japan
item.description: Chinese state media say China has sent two fighter planes to investigate flights by a dozen United States and Japanese planes in its newly established maritime air defense zone over the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thai Protesters Storm Army Headquarters
item.description: Protesters in Thailand stormed the grounds of the national army headquarters on Friday, asking the military to support their increasingly aggressive campaign to topple Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra. The army insisted it will not take sides in the dispute.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Drone Strike Kills Suspected Militant, Pakistani Official Says
item.description: The attack drew new criticism from a Pakistani opposition party which called it a sign of American contempt for the country’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Mixed Legacy for Departing Pakistani Army Chief
item.description: As the taciturn Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani steps down, little has changed in the American-Pakistani relationship despite years of diplomatic effort.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, the Pakistani Army chief, with Chinese soldiers in Pakistan in 2011.

item.title: U.N. Draws Attention to Plight of Syrian Refugee Children
item.description: A report from the High Commissioner for Refugees on Friday warned of a generation “traumatized, isolated and suffering” as a result of the Syrian conflict.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A Syrian boy waited for customers in Beirut. The United Nations has registered more than 1.1 million children among the total of 2.2 million refugees.

item.title: India Ink: Andhra Pradesh Heaves Sigh of Relief as Cyclone Lehar Becomes Deep Depression
item.description: The storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Fishermen in Gopalpur, Odisha, on Wednesday walking homeward after a cyclone alert in the area. Odisha and Andhra Pradesh are expected to receive heavy rainfall with the coming of Lehar.

item.title: India Ink: In Bihar Village, an Enduring Love for Lalu Prasad Yadav
item.description: The author recalls, “more than a chief minister of the state, he was a character of folklore for us.”
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lalu Prasad Yadav, former chief minister of Bihar, during an election campaign in Barachatti, Bihar on Nov. 15, 2010.

item.title: U.S. General Apologizes After Afghan Drone Strike
item.description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan that the United States regrets any civilian casualties that resulted from a drone strike in southern Helmand Province.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Isolation Under House Arrest for Wife of Imprisoned Nobel Laureate
item.description: Liu Xia, the wife of the Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo, says she finds joy in reading. “My reading has no specific goal; for me it’s rather like breathing — I have to do it in order to live,” she wrote in a letter.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Eases Rules on the Coveted Pilot’s License
item.description: The move by the Civil Aviation Administration of China is likely to unleash pent-up demand in the country’s civil aviation sector.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: A visitor sitting in the pilot's seat of a Cessna Grand Caravan aircraft during the Shanghai International Business Aviation Show in April.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Adam Minter on Why China’s Scrap Trade Helps the Environment
item.description: Desperate for resources to fuel its fast-growing economy, China has become the world’s biggest importer of garbage: scrap paper, metals, wires and plastic. And while reprocessing discarded electronics and other goods can exact a toll on the environment, recycling can be less polluting than extracting the raw materials from mines, oil wells or forests.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A worker carrying a scrapped computer monitor at a waste collection market in Beijing.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Prominent Activist Is Arrested
item.description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, a blogger who rose to prominence in the 2011 revolution, was held Thursday night on charges of inciting a demonstration in defiance of a new law heavily restricting protests, his family said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
item.description: Some stories that Bloomberg runs are considered too sensitive to run in China, raising questions about a clash of journalistic ideals with commercial interests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Matthew Winkler, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
item.description: Some stories that Bloomberg runs are considered too sensitive to run in China, raising questions about a clash of journalistic ideals with commercial interests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Matthew Winkler, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News.
